title: Jeremy Corbyn refuses to say he’ll stand-down if Labour lose election
text:
To view this video please enable JavaScript, and consider upgrading to a web browser that supports HTML5 video

Jeremy Corbyn has refused to say whether he will stand-down as Labour leader if the party loses the next general election.

Earlier this weekend Shadow Chancellor John McDonnell told GQ Magazine he ‘can’t see’ how the opposition leader will stay on if the party is not voted in this time.

But appearing on Sophy Ridge on Sunday today, Corbyn failed to answer the question, stating that Labour is ‘not expecting to lose the next election’.

He added that it is ‘up to the members of our party to decide who the leader is’.

Corbyn continued: ‘I am leading this party to go into an election. We have hundreds of thousands of members determined to win that election.

Jeremy Corbyn refused to say whether he would step down (Picture: Sky News)

He called the question ‘hypothetical’ (Picture: Sky News)

‘I am utterly determined to get a message out there that it is only Labour who are going to end austerity and invest in a better future for this country, and I want to lead the party to do that.’

He was then asked whether he believed the next Labour leader should be female, after Birmingham Yardley MP Jess Phillips said she is considering throwing her hat in the ring.

Speaking on Friday at the Cheltenham Literature Festival about her plans, she said: ‘I’d have to see how the land lay at that moment.’

Vet who took her own life in hospital 'gave up' after being let down by medics

Corbyn told Sophy Ridge: ‘It’s not for me to decide who the next leader is. Obviously a woman will be a candidate, of that I’ve very very sure.’

He added that he was not in the business of ‘ordaining’ anyone, but pointed out more women had been appointed to the front bench and shadow cabinet than ‘ever before’ under his leadership.

The Labour Party are already ready for the ‘strong possibility’ of a general election before Christmas, Corbyn also said during the interview.

He indicated that the party would hold a second referendum after the election, should they be voted in.

Jess Phillips said she could put herself forward if Corbyn steps down (Picture: PA)

If elected, he said he would aim to reach an agreement with the EU within three months, before holding a referendum within six months.

The government would then implement the result of that election ‘between a sensible relationship with Europe and remain’, he added.

Boris Johnson will head to the EU summit this week in his final bid to seek a Brexit deal ahead the UK’s Halloween deadline.

Tomorrow, the Prime Minister’s plans for post-Brexit Britain will be laid out in the Queen’s Speech, as the current parliament suspension comes to an end.

Plans to end free movement and provide faster access to medicines will be unveiled, government sources have said.

Ministers say a Brexit deal is a ‘priority’ and they hope one can be passed through Parliament ‘at pace’.

description: Jeremy Corbyn refused to answer Sophy Ridge on whether he will stand-down as Labour leader if the party loses the next general election.
